notes:
1. Definition

A polytropic process is a generalized thermodynamic process that follows the relation:

$$PV^n = \text{constant}$$

where $n$ is the polytropic index, which can be any real number. This single equation can be used to describe a wide range of processes by changing the value of $n$.

2. Special Cases

The polytropic process includes other common processes as special cases:

  • $n = 0$: $PV^0 = P = \text{constant}$ (Isobaric process)
  • $n = 1$: $PV^1 = PV = \text{constant}$ (Isothermal process for an ideal gas)
  • $n = k$: $PV^k = \text{constant}$ (Adiabatic process for an ideal gas, where $k=c_p/c_v$)
  • $n \to \infty$: (Isochoric process)

3. Work Done

The work done during a polytropic process is given by:

$$W = \frac{P_2V_2 - P_1V_1}{1-n} \quad \text{(for } n \neq 1\text{)}$$

For the case where $n=1$ (isothermal), the work formula is $W = P_1V_1 \ln(V_2/V_1)$.

solvedExamples.question: A polytropic process with an index $n=0$ is also known as what type of process?
solvedExamples.explanation: If $n=0$, the polytropic relation $PV^n = C$ becomes $PV^0 = P(1) = P = C$. This means the pressure is constant, which is the definition of an isobaric process.

solvedExamples.question: For an ideal gas, an adiabatic process is a polytropic process with the index $n$ equal to what?
solvedExamples.explanation: A reversible adiabatic process for an ideal gas is described by the relation $PV^k = C$, where $k=c_p/c_v$. This is a special case of the polytropic relation $PV^n = C$ with $n=k$.
